block.p: Dr. Afrodesia Egyptia McCannon and Brian Conrad Zumhagen were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Philip J. Kelly performed the ceremony at St. Joseph of the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church.

Dr. McCannon, 34, will continue to use her name professionally. She was until May an adjunct assistant professor of English at Queens College in Flushing. Next week, she is to become a Fulbright scholar at the University of Tunis, in Tunisia, where she will teach in the English department and research the death in 1270 in Tunis of King Louis IX of France, who was there during the Crusades. She graduated from Oberlin College in Ohio, and received a Ph.D. in comparative literature from the University of California at Berkeley. Her father, Percival McCannon of the Bronx, retired as a certified public accountant in the Bronx and was a sculptor and oil painter. Her mother, Dindga F. McCannon of Manhattan, is an artist who works with textiles.
frodesia Egyptia McCannon and Brian Conrad Zumhagen were married yesterday in Manhattan at St. Joseph of the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church.
Dr. Afrodesia Egyptia McCannon and Brian Conrad Zumhagen were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Philip J. Kelly performed the ceremony at St. Joseph of the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church.

Dr. McCannon, 34, will continue to use her name professionally. She was until May an adjunct assistant professor of English at Queens College in Flushing. Next week, she is to become a Fulbright scholar at the University of Tunis, in Tunisia, where she will teach in the English department and research the death in 1270 in Tunis of King Louis IX of France, who was there during the Crusades. She graduated from Oberlin College in Ohio, and received a Ph.D. in comparative literature from the University of California at Berkeley. Her father, Percival McCannon of the Bronx, retired as a certified public accountant in the Bronx and was a sculptor and oil painter. Her mother, Dindga F. McCannon of Manhattan, is an artist who works with textiles.

Mr. Zumhagen, 32, was until last week an editor at Columbia Digital Knowledge Ventures in Manhattan, which develops online versions of courses at Columbia University. He has also been an independent producer and reporter for public radio, and next week, he is to begin studying French and Arabic in Tunis. He graduated from Berkeley. He is the son of Patricia L. Zumhagen of Worthington, Ohio, and Conrad F. Zumhagen of Ann Arbor, Mich. His mother is an English teacher at Linworth Alternative School in Worthington, and coordinates a program that places the school's seniors in working internships in their last semester of school. His father is an independent marketing consultant in Ann Arbor for manufacturers of automotive plastics.
